Chapter 1.1:1: This is the list of the ancestors of Jesus Christ, a descendant of David, who was a descendant of Abraham.

Chapter 1.1:2-6: From Abraham to King David, the following ancestors are listed: Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Judah and his brothers; then Perez and Zerah their mother was Tamar, Hezron, Ram, Amminadab, Nahshon, Salmon, Boaz his mother was Rahab, Obed his mother was Ruth, Jesse, and King David.

Chapter 1.1:11: 7-From David to the time when the people of Israel were taken into exile in Babylon, the following ancestors are listed: David, Solomon his mother was the woman who had been Uriah's wife, Rehoboam, Abijah, Asa, Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, Hezekiah, Manasseh, Amon, Josiah, and Jehoiachin and his brothers.

Chapter 1.1:16: 12-From the time after the exile in Babylon to the birth of Jesus, the following ancestors are listed: Jehoiachin, Shealtiel, Zerubbabel, Abiud, Eliakim, Azor, Zadok, Achim, Eliud, Eleazar, Matthan, Jacob, and Joseph, who married Mary, the mother of Jesus, who was called the Messiah.

Chapter 1.1:17: So then, there were fourteen generations from Abraham to David, and fourteen from David to the exile in Babylon, and fourteen from then to the birth of the Messiah.

Chapter 1.1:18: This was how the birth of Jesus Christ took place. His mother Mary was engaged to Joseph, but before they were married, she found out that she was going to have a baby by the Holy Spirit.

Chapter 1.1:19: Joseph was a man who always did what was right, but he did not want to disgrace Mary publicly; so he made plans to break the engagement privately.

Chapter 1.1:20: While he was thinking about this, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said, Joseph, descendant of David, do not be afraid to take Mary to be your wife. For it is by the Holy Spirit that she has conceived.

Chapter 1.1:21: She will have a son, and you will name him Jesus—because he will save his people from their sins.

Chapter 1.1:22: Now all this happened in order to make come true what the Lord had said through the prophet,

Chapter 1.1:23: A virgin will become pregnant and have a son, and he will be called Immanuel which means, God is with us.

Chapter 1.1:24: So when Joseph woke up, he married Mary, as the angel of the Lord had told him to.

Chapter 1.1:25: But he had no sexual relations with her before she gave birth to her son. And Joseph named him Jesus.

Chapter 7.7:1: Do not judge others, so that God will not judge you,

Chapter 7.7:2: for God will judge you in the same way you judge others, and he will apply to you the same rules you apply to others.

Chapter 7.7:3: Why, then, do you look at the speck in your brother's eye and pay no attention to the log in your own eye?

Chapter 7.7:4: How dare you say to your brother, Please, let me take that speck out of your eye, when you have a log in your own eye?

Chapter 7.7:5: You hypocrite! First take the log out of your own eye, and then you will be able to see clearly to take the speck out of your brother's eye.

Chapter 7.7:6: Do not give what is holy to dogs—they will only turn and attack you. Do not throw your pearls in front of pigs—they will only trample them underfoot.

Chapter 7.7:7: Ask, and you will receive; seek, and you will find; knock, and the door will be opened to you.

Chapter 7.7:8: For everyone who asks will receive, and anyone who seeks will find, and the door will be opened to those who knock.

Chapter 7.7:9: Would any of you who are fathers give your son a stone when he asks for bread?

Chapter 7.7:10: Or would you give him a snake when he asks for a fish?

Chapter 7.7:11: As bad as you are, you know how to give good things to your children. How much more, then, will your Father in heaven give good things to those who ask him!

Chapter 7.7:12: Do for others what you want them to do for you: this is the meaning of the Law of Moses and of the teachings of the prophets.

Chapter 7.7:13: Go in through the narrow gate, because the gate to hell is wide and the road that leads to it is easy, and there are many who travel it.

Chapter 7.7:14: But the gate to life is narrow and the way that leads to it is hard, and there are few people who find it.

Chapter 7.7:15: Be on your guard against false prophets; they come to you looking like sheep on the outside, but on the inside they are really like wild wolves.

Chapter 7.7:16: You will know them by what they do. Thorn bushes do not bear grapes, and briers do not bear figs.

Chapter 7.7:17: A healthy tree bears good fruit, but a poor tree bears bad fruit.

Chapter 7.7:18: A healthy tree cannot bear bad fruit, and a poor tree cannot bear good fruit.

Chapter 7.7:19: And any tree that does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown in the fire.

Chapter 7.7:20: So then, you will know the false prophets by what they do.

Chapter 7.7:21: Not everyone who calls me Lord, Lord will enter the Kingdom of heaven, but only those who do what my Father in heaven wants them to do.

Chapter 7.7:22: When the Judgment Day comes, many will say to me, Lord, Lord! In your name we spoke God's message, by your name we drove out many demons and performed many miracles!

Chapter 7.7:23: Then I will say to them, I never knew you. Get away from me, you wicked people!

Chapter 7.7:24: So then, anyone who hears these words of mine and obeys them is like a wise man who built his house on rock.

Chapter 7.7:25: The rain poured down, the rivers flooded over, and the wind blew hard against that house. But it did not fall, because it was built on rock.

Chapter 7.7:26: But anyone who hears these words of mine and does not obey them is like a foolish man who built his house on sand.

Chapter 7.7:27: The rain poured down, the rivers flooded over, the wind blew hard against that house, and it fell. And what a terrible fall that was!

Chapter 7.7:28: When Jesus finished saying these things, the crowd was amazed at the way he taught.

Chapter 7.7:29: He wasn't like the teachers of the Law; instead, he taught with authority.

Chapter 8.8:1: When Jesus came down from the hill, large crowds followed him.

Chapter 8.8:2: Then a man suffering from a dreaded skin disease came to him, knelt down before him, and said, Sir, if you want to, you can make me clean.

Chapter 8.8:3: Jesus reached out and touched him. I do want to, he answered. Be clean! At once the man was healed of his disease.

Chapter 8.8:4: Then Jesus said to him, Listen! Don't tell anyone, but go straight to the priest and let him examine you; then in order to prove to everyone that you are cured, offer the sacrifice that Moses ordered.

Chapter 8.8:5: When Jesus entered Capernaum, a Roman officer met him and begged for help:

Chapter 8.8:6: Sir, my servant is sick in bed at home, unable to move and suffering terribly.

Chapter 8.8:7: I will go and make him well, Jesus said.

Chapter 8.8:8: Oh no, sir, answered the officer. I do not deserve to have you come into my house. Just give the order, and my servant will get well.

Chapter 8.8:9: I, too, am a man under the authority of superior officers, and I have soldiers under me. I order this one, Go! and he goes; and I order that one, Come! and he comes; and I order my slave, Do this! and he does it.

Chapter 8.8:10: When Jesus heard this, he was surprised and said to the people following him, I tell you, I have never found anyone in Israel with faith like this.

Chapter 8.8:11: I assure you that many will come from the east and the west and sit down with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob at the feast in the Kingdom of heaven.

Chapter 8.8:12: But those who should be in the Kingdom will be thrown out into the darkness, where they will cry and gnash their teeth.

Chapter 8.8:13: Then Jesus said to the officer, Go home, and what you believe will be done for you. And the officer's servant was healed that very moment.

Chapter 8.8:14: Jesus went to Peter's home, and there he saw Peter's mother-in-law sick in bed with a fever.

Chapter 8.8:15: He touched her hand; the fever left her, and she got up and began to wait on him.

Chapter 8.8:16: When evening came, people brought to Jesus many who had demons in them. Jesus drove out the evil spirits with a word and healed all who were sick.

Chapter 8.8:17: He did this to make come true what the prophet Isaiah had said, He himself took our sickness and carried away our diseases.

Chapter 8.8:18: When Jesus noticed the crowd around him, he ordered his disciples to go to the other side of the lake.

Chapter 8.8:19: A teacher of the Law came to him. Teacher, he said, I am ready to go with you wherever you go.

Chapter 8.8:20: Jesus answered him, Foxes have holes, and birds have nests, but the Son of Man has no place to lie down and rest.

Chapter 8.8:21: Another man, who was a disciple, said, Sir, first let me go back and bury my father.

Chapter 8.8:22: Follow me, Jesus answered, and let the dead bury their own dead.

Chapter 8.8:23: Jesus got into a boat, and his disciples went with him.

Chapter 8.8:24: Suddenly a fierce storm hit the lake, and the boat was in danger of sinking. But Jesus was asleep.

Chapter 8.8:25: The disciples went to him and woke him up. Save us, Lord! they said. We are about to die!

Chapter 8.8:26: Why are you so frightened? Jesus answered. What little faith you have! Then he got up and ordered the winds and the waves to stop, and there was a great calm.

Chapter 8.8:27: Everyone was amazed. What kind of man is this? they said. Even the winds and the waves obey him!

Chapter 8.8:28: When Jesus came to the territory of Gadara on the other side of the lake, he was met by two men who came out of the burial caves there. These men had demons in them and were so fierce that no one dared travel on that road.

Chapter 8.8:29: At once they screamed, What do you want with us, you Son of God? Have you come to punish us before the right time?

Chapter 8.8:30: Not far away there was a large herd of pigs feeding.

Chapter 8.8:31: So the demons begged Jesus, If you are going to drive us out, send us into that herd of pigs.

Chapter 8.8:32: Go, Jesus told them; so they left and went off into the pigs. The whole herd rushed down the side of the cliff into the lake and was drowned.

Chapter 8.8:33: The men who had been taking care of the pigs ran away and went into the town, where they told the whole story and what had happened to the men with the demons.

Chapter 8.8:34: So everyone from the town went out to meet Jesus; and when they saw him, they begged him to leave their territory.

Chapter 9.9:1: Jesus got into the boat and went back across the lake to his own town,

Chapter 9.9:2: where some people brought to him a paralyzed man, lying on a bed. When Jesus saw how much faith they had, he said to the paralyzed man, Courage, my son! Your sins are forgiven.

Chapter 9.9:3: Then some teachers of the Law said to themselves, This man is speaking blasphemy!

Chapter 9.9:4: Jesus perceived what they were thinking, and so he said, Why are you thinking such evil things?

Chapter 9.9:5: Is it easier to say, Your sins are forgiven, or to say, Get up and walk?

Chapter 9.9:6: I will prove to you, then, that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins. So he said to the paralyzed man, Get up, pick up your bed, and go home!

Chapter 9.9:7: The man got up and went home.

Chapter 9.9:8: When the people saw it, they were afraid, and praised God for giving such authority to people.

Chapter 9.9:9: Jesus left that place, and as he walked along, he saw a tax collector, named Matthew, sitting in his office. He said to him, Follow me. Matthew got up and followed him.

Chapter 9.9:10: While Jesus was having a meal in Matthew's house, many tax collectors and other outcasts came and joined Jesus and his disciples at the table.

Chapter 9.9:11: Some Pharisees saw this and asked his disciples, Why does your teacher eat with such people?

Chapter 9.9:12: Jesus heard them and answered, People who are well do not need a doctor, but only those who are sick.

Chapter 9.9:13: Go and find out what is meant by the scripture that says: It is kindness that I want, not animal sacrifices. I have not come to call respectable people, but outcasts.

Chapter 9.9:14: Then the followers of John the Baptist came to Jesus, asking, Why is it that we and the Pharisees fast often, but your disciples don't fast at all?

Chapter 9.9:15: Jesus answered, Do you expect the guests at a wedding party to be sad as long as the bridegroom is with them? Of course not! But the day will come when the bridegroom will be taken away from them, and then they will fast.

Chapter 9.9:16: No one patches up an old coat with a piece of new cloth, for the new patch will shrink and make an even bigger hole in the coat.

Chapter 9.9:17: Nor does anyone pour new wine into used wineskins, for the skins will burst, the wine will pour out, and the skins will be ruined. Instead, new wine is poured into fresh wineskins, and both will keep in good condition.

Chapter 9.9:18: While Jesus was saying this, a Jewish official came to him, knelt down before him, and said, My daughter has just died; but come and place your hands on her, and she will live.

Chapter 9.9:19: So Jesus got up and followed him, and his disciples went along with him.

Chapter 9.9:20: A woman who had suffered from severe bleeding for twelve years came up behind Jesus and touched the edge of his cloak.

Chapter 9.9:21: She said to herself, If only I touch his cloak, I will get well.

Chapter 9.9:22: Jesus turned around and saw her, and said, Courage, my daughter! Your faith has made you well. At that very moment the woman became well.

Chapter 9.9:23: Then Jesus went into the official's house. When he saw the musicians for the funeral and the people all stirred up,

Chapter 9.9:24: he said, Get out, everybody! The little girl is not dead—she is only sleeping! Then they all started making fun of him.

Chapter 9.9:25: But as soon as the people had been put out, Jesus went into the girl's room and took hold of her hand, and she got up.

Chapter 9.9:26: The news about this spread all over that part of the country.

Chapter 9.9:27: Jesus left that place, and as he walked along, two blind men started following him. Have mercy on us, Son of David! they shouted.

Chapter 9.9:28: When Jesus had gone indoors, the two blind men came to him, and he asked them, Do you believe that I can heal you? Yes, sir! they answered.

Chapter 9.9:29: Then Jesus touched their eyes and said, Let it happen, then, just as you believe!—

Chapter 9.9:30: and their sight was restored. Jesus spoke sternly to them, Don't tell this to anyone!

Chapter 9.9:31: But they left and spread the news about Jesus all over that part of the country.

Chapter 9.9:32: As the men were leaving, some people brought to Jesus a man who could not talk because he had a demon.

Chapter 9.9:33: But as soon as the demon was driven out, the man started talking, and everyone was amazed. We have never seen anything like this in Israel! they exclaimed.

Chapter 9.9:34: But the Pharisees said, It is the chief of the demons who gives Jesus the power to drive out demons.

Chapter 9.9:35: Jesus went around visiting all the towns and villages. He taught in the synagogues, preached the Good News about the Kingdom, and healed people with every kind of disease and sickness.

Chapter 9.9:36: As he saw the crowds, his heart was filled with pity for them, because they were worried and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd.

Chapter 9.9:37: So he said to his disciples, The harvest is large, but there are few workers to gather it in.

Chapter 9.9:38: Pray to the owner of the harvest that he will send out workers to gather in his harvest.

Chapter 10.10:1: Jesus called his twelve disciples together and gave them authority to drive out evil spirits and to heal every disease and every sickness.

Chapter 10.10:2: These are the names of the twelve apostles: first, Simon called Peter and his brother Andrew; James and his brother John, the sons of Zebedee;

Chapter 10.10:3: Philip and Bartholomew; Thomas and Matthew, the tax collector; James son of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus;

Chapter 10.10:4: Simon the Patriot, and Judas Iscariot, who betrayed Jesus.

Chapter 10.10:5: These twelve men were sent out by Jesus with the following instructions: Do not go to any Gentile territory or any Samaritan towns.

Chapter 10.10:6: Instead, you are to go to the lost sheep of the people of Israel.

Chapter 10.10:7: Go and preach, The Kingdom of heaven is near!

Chapter 10.10:8: Heal the sick, bring the dead back to life, heal those who suffer from dreaded skin diseases, and drive out demons. You have received without paying, so give without being paid.

Chapter 10.10:9: Do not carry any gold, silver, or copper money in your pockets;

Chapter 10.10:10: do not carry a beggar's bag for the trip or an extra shirt or shoes or a walking stick. Workers should be given what they need.

Chapter 10.10:11: When you come to a town or village, go in and look for someone who is willing to welcome you, and stay with him until you leave that place.

Chapter 10.10:12: When you go into a house, say, Peace be with you.

Chapter 10.10:13: If the people in that house welcome you, let your greeting of peace remain; but if they do not welcome you, then take back your greeting.

Chapter 10.10:14: And if some home or town will not welcome you or listen to you, then leave that place and shake the dust off your feet.

Chapter 10.10:15: I assure you that on the Judgment Day God will show more mercy to the people of Sodom and Gomorrah than to the people of that town!

Chapter 10.10:16: Listen! I am sending you out just like sheep to a pack of wolves. You must be as cautious as snakes and as gentle as doves.

Chapter 10.10:17: Watch out, for there will be those who will arrest you and take you to court, and they will whip you in the synagogues.

Chapter 10.10:18: For my sake you will be brought to trial before rulers and kings, to tell the Good News to them and to the Gentiles.

Chapter 10.10:19: When they bring you to trial, do not worry about what you are going to say or how you will say it; when the time comes, you will be given what you will say.

Chapter 10.10:20: For the words you will speak will not be yours; they will come from the Spirit of your Father speaking through you.

Chapter 10.10:21: People will hand over their own brothers to be put to death, and fathers will do the same to their children; children will turn against their parents and have them put to death.

Chapter 10.10:22: Everyone will hate you because of me. But whoever holds out to the end will be saved.

Chapter 10.10:23: When they persecute you in one town, run away to another one. I assure you that you will not finish your work in all the towns of Israel before the Son of Man comes.

Chapter 10.10:24: No pupil is greater than his teacher; no slave is greater than his master.

Chapter 10.10:25: So a pupil should be satisfied to become like his teacher, and a slave like his master. If the head of the family is called Beelzebul, the members of the family will be called even worse names!

Chapter 10.10:26: So do not be afraid of people. Whatever is now covered up will be uncovered, and every secret will be made known.

Chapter 10.10:27: What I am telling you in the dark you must repeat in broad daylight, and what you have heard in private you must announce from the housetops.

Chapter 10.10:28: Do not be afraid of those who kill the body but cannot kill the soul; rather be afraid of God, who can destroy both body and soul in hell.

Chapter 10.10:29: For only a penny you can buy two sparrows, yet not one sparrow falls to the ground without your Father's consent.

Chapter 10.10:30: As for you, even the hairs of your head have all been counted.

Chapter 10.10:31: So do not be afraid; you are worth much more than many sparrows!

Chapter 10.10:32: Those who declare publicly that they belong to me, I will do the same for them before my Father in heaven.

Chapter 10.10:33: But those who reject me publicly, I will reject before my Father in heaven.

Chapter 10.10:34: Do not think that I have come to bring peace to the world. No, I did not come to bring peace, but a sword.

Chapter 10.10:35: I came to set sons against their fathers, daughters against their mothers, daughters-in-law against their mothers-in-law;

Chapter 10.10:36: your worst enemies will be the members of your own family.

Chapter 10.10:37: Those who love their father or mother more than me are not fit to be my disciples; those who love their son or daughter more than me are not fit to be my disciples.

Chapter 10.10:38: Those who do not take up their cross and follow in my steps are not fit to be my disciples.

Chapter 10.10:39: Those who try to gain their own life will lose it; but those who lose their life for my sake will gain it.

Chapter 10.10:40: Whoever welcomes you welcomes me; and whoever welcomes me welcomes the one who sent me.

Chapter 10.10:41: Whoever welcomes God's messenger because he is God's messenger, will share in his reward. And whoever welcomes a good man because he is good, will share in his reward.

Chapter 10.10:42: You can be sure that whoever gives even a drink of cold water to one of the least of these my followers because he is my follower, will certainly receive a reward.

Chapter 11.11:1: When Jesus finished giving these instructions to his twelve disciples, he left that place and went off to teach and preach in the towns near there.

Chapter 11.11:2: When John the Baptist heard in prison about the things that Christ was doing, he sent some of his disciples to him.

Chapter 11.11:3: Tell us, they asked Jesus, are you the one John said was going to come, or should we expect someone else?

Chapter 11.11:4: Jesus answered, Go back and tell John what you are hearing and seeing:

Chapter 11.11:5: the blind can see, the lame can walk, those who suffer from dreaded skin diseases are made clean, the deaf hear, the dead are brought back to life, and the Good News is preached to the poor.

Chapter 11.11:6: How happy are those who have no doubts about me!

Chapter 11.11:7: While John's disciples were leaving, Jesus spoke about him to the crowds: When you went out to John in the desert, what did you expect to see? A blade of grass bending in the wind?

Chapter 11.11:8: What did you go out to see? A man dressed up in fancy clothes? People who dress like that live in palaces!

Chapter 11.11:9: Tell me, what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes indeed, but you saw much more than a prophet.

Chapter 11.11:10: For John is the one of whom the scripture says: God said, I will send my messenger ahead of you to open the way for you.

Chapter 11.11:11: I assure you that John the Baptist is greater than anyone who has ever lived. But the one who is least in the Kingdom of heaven is greater than John.

Chapter 11.11:12: From the time John preached his message until this very day the Kingdom of heaven has suffered violent attacks, and violent men try to seize it.

Chapter 11.11:13: Until the time of John all the prophets and the Law of Moses spoke about the Kingdom;

Chapter 11.11:14: and if you are willing to believe their message, John is Elijah, whose coming was predicted.

Chapter 11.11:15: Listen, then, if you have ears!

Chapter 11.11:16: Now, to what can I compare the people of this day? They are like children sitting in the marketplace. One group shouts to the other,

Chapter 11.11:17: We played wedding music for you, but you wouldn't dance! We sang funeral songs, but you wouldn't cry!

Chapter 11.11:18: When John came, he fasted and drank no wine, and everyone said, He has a demon in him!

Chapter 11.11:19: When the Son of Man came, he ate and drank, and everyone said, Look at this man! He is a glutton and wine drinker, a friend of tax collectors and other outcasts! God's wisdom, however, is shown to be true by its results.

Chapter 11.11:20: The people in the towns where Jesus had performed most of his miracles did not turn from their sins, so he reproached those towns.

Chapter 11.11:21: How terrible it will be for you, Chorazin! How terrible for you too, Bethsaida! If the miracles which were performed in you had been performed in Tyre and Sidon, the people there would have long ago put on sackcloth and sprinkled ashes on themselves, to show that they had turned from their sins!

Chapter 11.11:22: I assure you that on the Judgment Day God will show more mercy to the people of Tyre and Sidon than to you!

Chapter 11.11:23: And as for you, Capernaum! Did you want to lift yourself up to heaven? You will be thrown down to hell! If the miracles which were performed in you had been performed in Sodom, it would still be in existence today!

Chapter 11.11:24: You can be sure that on the Judgment Day God will show more mercy to Sodom than to you!

Chapter 11.11:25: At that time Jesus said, Father, Lord of heaven and earth! I thank you because you have shown to the unlearned what you have hidden from the wise and learned.

Chapter 11.11:26: Yes, Father, this was how you were pleased to have it happen.

Chapter 11.11:27: My Father has given me all things. No one knows the Son except the Father, and no one knows the Father except the Son and those to whom the Son chooses to reveal him.

Chapter 11.11:28: Come to me, all of you who are tired from carrying heavy loads, and I will give you rest.

Chapter 11.11:29: Take my yoke and put it on you, and learn from me, because I am gentle and humble in spirit; and you will find rest.

Chapter 11.11:30: For the yoke I will give you is easy, and the load I will put on you is light.

Chapter 14.14:1: At that time Herod, the ruler of Galilee, heard about Jesus.

Chapter 14.14:2: He is really John the Baptist, who has come back to life, he told his officials. That is why he has this power to perform miracles.

Chapter 14.14:3: For Herod had earlier ordered John's arrest, and he had him tied up and put in prison. He had done this because of Herodias, his brother Philip's wife.

Chapter 14.14:4: For some time John the Baptist had told Herod, It isn't right for you to be married to Herodias!

Chapter 14.14:5: Herod wanted to kill him, but he was afraid of the Jewish people, because they considered John to be a prophet.

Chapter 14.14:6: On Herod's birthday the daughter of Herodias danced in front of the whole group. Herod was so pleased

Chapter 14.14:7: that he promised her, I swear that I will give you anything you ask for!

Chapter 14.14:8: At her mother's suggestion she asked him, Give me here and now the head of John the Baptist on a plate!

Chapter 14.14:9: The king was sad, but because of the promise he had made in front of all his guests he gave orders that her wish be granted.

Chapter 14.14:10: So he had John beheaded in prison.

Chapter 14.14:11: The head was brought in on a plate and given to the girl, who took it to her mother.

Chapter 14.14:12: John's disciples came, carried away his body, and buried it; then they went and told Jesus.

Chapter 14.14:13: When Jesus heard the news about John, he left there in a boat and went to a lonely place by himself. The people heard about it, and so they left their towns and followed him by land.

Chapter 14.14:14: Jesus got out of the boat, and when he saw the large crowd, his heart was filled with pity for them, and he healed their sick.

Chapter 14.14:15: That evening his disciples came to him and said, It is already very late, and this is a lonely place. Send the people away and let them go to the villages to buy food for themselves.

Chapter 14.14:16: They don't have to leave, answered Jesus. You yourselves give them something to eat!

Chapter 14.14:17: All we have here are five loaves and two fish, they replied.

Chapter 14.14:18: Then bring them here to me, Jesus said.

Chapter 14.14:19: He ordered the people to sit down on the grass; then he took the five loaves and the two fish, looked up to heaven, and gave thanks to God. He broke the loaves and gave them to the disciples, and the disciples gave them to the people.

Chapter 14.14:20: Everyone ate and had enough. Then the disciples took up twelve baskets full of what was left over.

Chapter 14.14:21: The number of men who ate was about five thousand, not counting the women and children.

Chapter 14.14:22: Then Jesus made the disciples get into the boat and go on ahead to the other side of the lake, while he sent the people away.

Chapter 14.14:23: After sending the people away, he went up a hill by himself to pray. When evening came, Jesus was there alone;

Chapter 14.14:24: and by this time the boat was far out in the lake, tossed about by the waves, because the wind was blowing against it.

Chapter 14.14:25: Between three and six o'clock in the morning Jesus came to the disciples, walking on the water.

Chapter 14.14:26: When they saw him walking on the water, they were terrified. It's a ghost! they said, and screamed with fear.

Chapter 14.14:27: Jesus spoke to them at once. Courage! he said. It is I. Don't be afraid!

Chapter 14.14:28: Then Peter spoke up. Lord, if it is really you, order me to come out on the water to you.

Chapter 14.14:29: Come! answered Jesus. So Peter got out of the boat and started walking on the water to Jesus.

Chapter 14.14:30: But when he noticed the strong wind, he was afraid and started to sink down in the water. Save me, Lord! he cried.

Chapter 14.14:31: At once Jesus reached out and grabbed hold of him and said, What little faith you have! Why did you doubt?

Chapter 14.14:32: They both got into the boat, and the wind died down.

Chapter 14.14:33: Then the disciples in the boat worshiped Jesus. Truly you are the Son of God! they exclaimed.

Chapter 14.14:34: They crossed the lake and came to land at Gennesaret,

Chapter 14.14:35: where the people recognized Jesus. So they sent for the sick people in all the surrounding country and brought them to Jesus.

Chapter 14.14:36: They begged him to let the sick at least touch the edge of his cloak; and all who touched it were made well.

Chapter 16.16:1: Some Pharisees and Sadducees who came to Jesus wanted to trap him, so they asked him to perform a miracle for them, to show that God approved of him.

Chapter 16.16:2: But Jesus answered, When the sun is setting, you say, We are going to have fine weather, because the sky is red.

Chapter 16.16:3: And early in the morning you say, It is going to rain, because the sky is red and dark. You can predict the weather by looking at the sky, but you cannot interpret the signs concerning these times!

Chapter 16.16:4: How evil and godless are the people of this day! You ask me for a miracle? No! The only miracle you will be given is the miracle of Jonah. So he left them and went away.

Chapter 16.16:5: When the disciples crossed over to the other side of the lake, they forgot to take any bread.

Chapter 16.16:6: Jesus said to them, Take care; be on your guard against the yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees.

Chapter 16.16:7: They started discussing among themselves, He says this because we didn't bring any bread.

Chapter 16.16:8: Jesus knew what they were saying, so he asked them, Why are you discussing among yourselves about not having any bread? What little faith you have!

Chapter 16.16:9: Don't you understand yet? Don't you remember when I broke the five loaves for the five thousand men? How many baskets did you fill?

Chapter 16.16:10: And what about the seven loaves for the four thousand men? How many baskets did you fill?

Chapter 16.16:11: How is it that you don't understand that I was not talking to you about bread? Guard yourselves from the yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees!

Chapter 16.16:12: Then the disciples understood that he was not warning them to guard themselves from the yeast used in bread but from the teaching of the Pharisees and Sadducees.

Chapter 16.16:13: Jesus went to the territory near the town of Caesarea Philippi, where he asked his disciples, Who do people say the Son of Man is?

Chapter 16.16:14: Some say John the Baptist, they answered. Others say Elijah, while others say Jeremiah or some other prophet.

Chapter 16.16:15: What about you? he asked them. Who do you say I am?

Chapter 16.16:16: Simon Peter answered, You are the Messiah, the Son of the living God.

Chapter 16.16:17: Good for you, Simon son of John! answered Jesus. For this truth did not come to you from any human being, but it was given to you directly by my Father in heaven.

Chapter 16.16:18: And so I tell you, Peter: you are a rock, and on this rock foundation I will build my church, and not even death will ever be able to overcome it.

Chapter 16.16:19: I will give you the keys of the Kingdom of heaven; what you prohibit on earth will be prohibited in heaven, and what you permit on earth will be permitted in heaven.

Chapter 16.16:20: Then Jesus ordered his disciples not to tell anyone that he was the Messiah.

Chapter 16.16:21: From that time on Jesus began to say plainly to his disciples, I must go to Jerusalem and suffer much from the elders, the chief priests, and the teachers of the Law. I will be put to death, but three days later I will be raised to life.

Chapter 16.16:22: Peter took him aside and began to rebuke him. God forbid it, Lord! he said. That must never happen to you!

Chapter 16.16:23: Jesus turned around and said to Peter, Get away from me, Satan! You are an obstacle in my way, because these thoughts of yours don't come from God, but from human nature.

Chapter 16.16:24: Then Jesus said to his disciples, If any of you want to come with me, you must forget yourself, carry your cross, and follow me.

Chapter 16.16:25: For if you want to save your own life, you will lose it; but if you lose your life for my sake, you will find it.

Chapter 16.16:26: Will you gain anything if you win the whole world but lose your life? Of course not! There is nothing you can give to regain your life.

Chapter 16.16:27: For the Son of Man is about to come in the glory of his Father with his angels, and then he will reward each one according to his deeds.

Chapter 16.16:28: I assure you that there are some here who will not die until they have seen the Son of Man come as King.

Chapter 17.17:1: Six days later Jesus took with him Peter and the brothers James and John and led them up a high mountain where they were alone.

Chapter 17.17:2: As they looked on, a change came over Jesus: his face was shining like the sun, and his clothes were dazzling white.

Chapter 17.17:3: Then the three disciples saw Moses and Elijah talking with Jesus.

Chapter 17.17:4: So Peter spoke up and said to Jesus, Lord, how good it is that we are here! If you wish, I will make three tents here, one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.

Chapter 17.17:5: While he was talking, a shining cloud came over them, and a voice from the cloud said, This is my own dear Son, with whom I am pleased—listen to him!

Chapter 17.17:6: When the disciples heard the voice, they were so terrified that they threw themselves face downward on the ground.

Chapter 17.17:7: Jesus came to them and touched them. Get up, he said. Don't be afraid!

Chapter 17.17:8: So they looked up and saw no one there but Jesus.

Chapter 17.17:9: As they came down the mountain, Jesus ordered them, Don't tell anyone about this vision you have seen until the Son of Man has been raised from death.

Chapter 17.17:10: Then the disciples asked Jesus, Why do the teachers of the Law say that Elijah has to come first?

Chapter 17.17:11: Elijah is indeed coming first, answered Jesus, and he will get everything ready.

Chapter 17.17:12: But I tell you that Elijah has already come and people did not recognize him, but treated him just as they pleased. In the same way they will also mistreat the Son of Man.

Chapter 17.17:13: Then the disciples understood that he was talking to them about John the Baptist.

Chapter 17.17:14: When they returned to the crowd, a man came to Jesus, knelt before him,

Chapter 17.17:15: and said, Sir, have mercy on my son! He is an epileptic and has such terrible attacks that he often falls in the fire or into water.

Chapter 17.17:16: I brought him to your disciples, but they could not heal him.

Chapter 17.17:17: Jesus answered, How unbelieving and wrong you people are! How long must I stay with you? How long do I have to put up with you? Bring the boy here to me!

Chapter 17.17:18: Jesus gave a command to the demon, and it went out of the boy, and at that very moment he was healed.

Chapter 17.17:19: Then the disciples came to Jesus in private and asked him, Why couldn't we drive the demon out?

Chapter 17.17:20: It was because you do not have enough faith, answered Jesus. I assure you that if you have faith as big as a mustard seed, you can say to this hill, Go from here to there! and it will go. You could do anything!

Chapter 17.17:22: When the disciples all came together in Galilee, Jesus said to them, The Son of Man is about to be handed over to those

Chapter 17.17:23: who will kill him; but three days later he will be raised to life. The disciples became very sad.

Chapter 17.17:24: When Jesus and his disciples came to Capernaum, the collectors of the Temple tax came to Peter and asked, Does your teacher pay the Temple tax?

Chapter 17.17:25: Of course, Peter answered. When Peter went into the house, Jesus spoke up first, Simon, what is your opinion? Who pays duties or taxes to the kings of this world? The citizens of the country or the foreigners?

Chapter 17.17:26: The foreigners, answered Peter. Well, then, replied Jesus, that means that the citizens don't have to pay.

Chapter 17.17:27: But we don't want to offend these people. So go to the lake and drop in a line. Pull up the first fish you hook, and in its mouth you will find a coin worth enough for my Temple tax and yours. Take it and pay them our taxes.

Chapter 18.18:1: At that time the disciples came to Jesus, asking, Who is the greatest in the Kingdom of heaven?

Chapter 18.18:2: So Jesus called a child to come and stand in front of them,

Chapter 18.18:3: and said, I assure you that unless you change and become like children, you will never enter the Kingdom of heaven.

Chapter 18.18:4: The greatest in the Kingdom of heaven is the one who humbles himself and becomes like this child.

Chapter 18.18:5: And whoever welcomes in my name one such child as this, welcomes me.

Chapter 18.18:6: If anyone should cause one of these little ones to lose his faith in me, it would be better for that person to have a large millstone tied around his neck and be drowned in the deep sea.

Chapter 18.18:7: How terrible for the world that there are things that make people lose their faith! Such things will always happen—but how terrible for the one who causes them!

Chapter 18.18:8: If your hand or your foot makes you lose your faith, cut it off and throw it away! It is better for you to enter life without a hand or a foot than to keep both hands and both feet and be thrown into the eternal fire.

Chapter 18.18:9: And if your eye makes you lose your faith, take it out and throw it away! It is better for you to enter life with only one eye than to keep both eyes and be thrown into the fire of hell.

Chapter 18.18:10: See that you don't despise any of these little ones. Their angels in heaven, I tell you, are always in the presence of my Father in heaven.

Chapter 18.18:12: What do you think a man does who has one hundred sheep and one of them gets lost? He will leave the other ninety-nine grazing on the hillside and go and look for the lost sheep.

Chapter 18.18:13: When he finds it, I tell you, he feels far happier over this one sheep than over the ninety-nine that did not get lost.

Chapter 18.18:14: In just the same way your Father in heaven does not want any of these little ones to be lost.

Chapter 18.18:15: If your brother sins against you, go to him and show him his fault. But do it privately, just between yourselves. If he listens to you, you have won your brother back.

Chapter 18.18:16: But if he will not listen to you, take one or two other persons with you, so that every accusation may be upheld by the testimony of two or more witnesses, as the scripture says.

Chapter 18.18:17: And if he will not listen to them, then tell the whole thing to the church. Finally, if he will not listen to the church, treat him as though he were a pagan or a tax collector.

Chapter 18.18:18: And so I tell all of you: what you prohibit on earth will be prohibited in heaven, and what you permit on earth will be permitted in heaven.

Chapter 18.18:19: And I tell you more: whenever two of you on earth agree about anything you pray for, it will be done for you by my Father in heaven.

Chapter 18.18:20: For where two or three come together in my name, I am there with them.

Chapter 18.18:21: Then Peter came to Jesus and asked, Lord, if my brother keeps on sinning against me, how many times do I have to forgive him? Seven times?

Chapter 18.18:22: No, not seven times, answered Jesus, but seventy times seven,

Chapter 18.18:23: because the Kingdom of heaven is like this. Once there was a king who decided to check on his servants' accounts.

Chapter 18.18:24: He had just begun to do so when one of them was brought in who owed him millions of dollars.

Chapter 18.18:25: The servant did not have enough to pay his debt, so the king ordered him to be sold as a slave, with his wife and his children and all that he had, in order to pay the debt.

Chapter 18.18:26: The servant fell on his knees before the king. Be patient with me, he begged, and I will pay you everything!

Chapter 18.18:27: The king felt sorry for him, so he forgave him the debt and let him go.

Chapter 18.18:28: Then the man went out and met one of his fellow servants who owed him a few dollars. He grabbed him and started choking him. Pay back what you owe me! he said.

Chapter 18.18:29: His fellow servant fell down and begged him, Be patient with me, and I will pay you back!

Chapter 18.18:30: But he refused; instead, he had him thrown into jail until he should pay the debt.

Chapter 18.18:31: When the other servants saw what had happened, they were very upset and went to the king and told him everything.

Chapter 18.18:32: So he called the servant in. You worthless slave! he said. I forgave you the whole amount you owed me, just because you asked me to.

Chapter 18.18:33: You should have had mercy on your fellow servant, just as I had mercy on you.

Chapter 18.18:34: The king was very angry, and he sent the servant to jail to be punished until he should pay back the whole amount.

Chapter 18.18:35: And Jesus concluded, That is how my Father in heaven will treat every one of you unless you forgive your brother from your heart.

Chapter 19.19:1: When Jesus finished saying these things, he left Galilee and went to the territory of Judea on the other side of the Jordan River.

Chapter 19.19:2: Large crowds followed him, and he healed them there.

Chapter 19.19:3: Some Pharisees came to him and tried to trap him by asking, Does our Law allow a man to divorce his wife for whatever reason he wishes?

Chapter 19.19:4: Jesus answered, Haven't you read the scripture that says that in the beginning the Creator made people male and female?

Chapter 19.19:5: And God said, For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and unite with his wife, and the two will become one.

Chapter 19.19:6: So they are no longer two, but one. No human being must separate, then, what God has joined together.

Chapter 19.19:7: The Pharisees asked him, Why, then, did Moses give the law for a man to hand his wife a divorce notice and send her away?

Chapter 19.19:8: Jesus answered, Moses gave you permission to divorce your wives because you are so hard to teach. But it was not like that at the time of creation.

Chapter 19.19:9: I tell you, then, that any man who divorces his wife for any cause other than her unfaithfulness, commits adultery if he marries some other woman.

Chapter 19.19:10: His disciples said to him, If this is how it is between a man and his wife, it is better not to marry.

Chapter 19.19:11: Jesus answered, This teaching does not apply to everyone, but only to those to whom God has given it.

Chapter 19.19:12: For there are different reasons why men cannot marry: some, because they were born that way; others, because men made them that way; and others do not marry for the sake of the Kingdom of heaven. Let him who can accept this teaching do so.

Chapter 19.19:13: Some people brought children to Jesus for him to place his hands on them and to pray for them, but the disciples scolded the people.

Chapter 19.19:14: Jesus said, Let the children come to me and do not stop them, because the Kingdom of heaven belongs to such as these.

Chapter 19.19:15: He placed his hands on them and then went away.

Chapter 19.19:16: Once a man came to Jesus. Teacher, he asked, what good thing must I do to receive eternal life?

Chapter 19.19:17: Why do you ask me concerning what is good? answered Jesus. There is only One who is good. Keep the commandments if you want to enter life.

Chapter 19.19:18: What commandments? he asked. Jesus answered, Do not commit murder; do not commit adultery; do not steal; do not accuse anyone falsely;

Chapter 19.19:19: respect your father and your mother; and love your neighbor as you love yourself.

Chapter 19.19:20: I have obeyed all these commandments, the young man replied. What else do I need to do?

Chapter 19.19:21: Jesus said to him, If you want to be perfect, go and sell all you have and give the money to the poor, and you will have riches in heaven; then come and follow me.

Chapter 19.19:22: When the young man heard this, he went away sad, because he was very rich.

Chapter 19.19:23: Jesus then said to his disciples, I assure you: it will be very hard for rich people to enter the Kingdom of heaven.

Chapter 19.19:24: I repeat: it is much harder for a rich person to enter the Kingdom of God than for a camel to go through the eye of a needle.

Chapter 19.19:25: When the disciples heard this, they were completely amazed. Who, then, can be saved? they asked.

Chapter 19.19:26: Jesus looked straight at them and answered, This is impossible for human beings, but for God everything is possible.

Chapter 19.19:27: Then Peter spoke up. Look, he said, we have left everything and followed you. What will we have?

Chapter 19.19:28: Jesus said to them, You can be sure that when the Son of Man sits on his glorious throne in the New Age, then you twelve followers of mine will also sit on thrones, to rule the twelve tribes of Israel.

Chapter 19.19:29: And everyone who has left houses or brothers or sisters or father or mother or children or fields for my sake, will receive a hundred times more and will be given eternal life.

Chapter 19.19:30: But many who now are first will be last, and many who now are last will be first.

Chapter 20.20:1: The Kingdom of heaven is like this. Once there was a man who went out early in the morning to hire some men to work in his vineyard.

Chapter 20.20:2: He agreed to pay them the regular wage, a silver coin a day, and sent them to work in his vineyard.

Chapter 20.20:3: He went out again to the marketplace at nine o'clock and saw some men standing there doing nothing,

Chapter 20.20:4: so he told them, You also go and work in the vineyard, and I will pay you a fair wage.

Chapter 20.20:5: So they went. Then at twelve o'clock and again at three o'clock he did the same thing.

Chapter 20.20:6: It was nearly five o'clock when he went to the marketplace and saw some other men still standing there. Why are you wasting the whole day here doing nothing? he asked them.

Chapter 20.20:7: No one hired us, they answered. Well, then, you go and work in the vineyard, he told them.

Chapter 20.20:8: When evening came, the owner told his foreman, Call the workers and pay them their wages, starting with those who were hired last and ending with those who were hired first.

Chapter 20.20:9: The men who had begun to work at five o'clock were paid a silver coin each.

Chapter 20.20:10: So when the men who were the first to be hired came to be paid, they thought they would get more; but they too were given a silver coin each.

Chapter 20.20:11: They took their money and started grumbling against the employer.

Chapter 20.20:12: These men who were hired last worked only one hour, they said, while we put up with a whole day's work in the hot sun—yet you paid them the same as you paid us!

Chapter 20.20:13: Listen, friend, the owner answered one of them, I have not cheated you. After all, you agreed to do a day's work for one silver coin.

Chapter 20.20:14: Now take your pay and go home. I want to give this man who was hired last as much as I gave you.

Chapter 20.20:15: Don't I have the right to do as I wish with my own money? Or are you jealous because I am generous?

Chapter 20.20:16: And Jesus concluded, So those who are last will be first, and those who are first will be last.

Chapter 20.20:17: As Jesus was going up to Jerusalem, he took the twelve disciples aside and spoke to them privately, as they walked along.

Chapter 20.20:18: Listen, he told them, we are going up to Jerusalem, where the Son of Man will be handed over to the chief priests and the teachers of the Law. They will condemn him to death

Chapter 20.20:19: and then hand him over to the Gentiles, who will make fun of him, whip him, and crucify him; but three days later he will be raised to life.

Chapter 20.20:20: Then the wife of Zebedee came to Jesus with her two sons, bowed before him, and asked him for a favor.

Chapter 20.20:21: What do you want? Jesus asked her. She answered, Promise me that these two sons of mine will sit at your right and your left when you are King.

Chapter 20.20:22: You don't know what you are asking for, Jesus answered the sons. Can you drink the cup of suffering that I am about to drink? We can, they answered.

Chapter 20.20:23: You will indeed drink from my cup, Jesus told them, but I do not have the right to choose who will sit at my right and my left. These places belong to those for whom my Father has prepared them.

Chapter 20.20:24: When the other ten disciples heard about this, they became angry with the two brothers.

Chapter 20.20:25: So Jesus called them all together and said, You know that the rulers of the heathen have power over them, and the leaders have complete authority.

Chapter 20.20:26: This, however, is not the way it shall be among you. If one of you wants to be great, you must be the servant of the rest;

Chapter 20.20:27: and if one of you wants to be first, you must be the slave of the others—

Chapter 20.20:28: like the Son of Man, who did not come to be served, but to serve and to give his life to redeem many people.

Chapter 20.20:29: As Jesus and his disciples were leaving Jericho, a large crowd was following.

Chapter 20.20:30: Two blind men who were sitting by the road heard that Jesus was passing by, so they began to shout, Son of David! Have mercy on us, sir!

Chapter 20.20:31: The crowd scolded them and told them to be quiet. But they shouted even more loudly, Son of David! Have mercy on us, sir!

Chapter 20.20:32: Jesus stopped and called them. What do you want me to do for you? he asked them.

Chapter 20.20:33: Sir, they answered, we want you to give us our sight!

Chapter 20.20:34: Jesus had pity on them and touched their eyes; at once they were able to see, and they followed him.

Chapter 23.23:1: Then Jesus spoke to the crowds and to his disciples.

Chapter 23.23:2: The teachers of the Law and the Pharisees are the authorized interpreters of Moses' Law.

Chapter 23.23:3: So you must obey and follow everything they tell you to do; do not, however, imitate their actions, because they don't practice what they preach.

Chapter 23.23:4: They tie onto people's backs loads that are heavy and hard to carry, yet they aren't willing even to lift a finger to help them carry those loads.

Chapter 23.23:5: They do everything so that people will see them. Look at the straps with scripture verses on them which they wear on their foreheads and arms, and notice how large they are! Notice also how long are the tassels on their cloaks!

Chapter 23.23:6: They love the best places at feasts and the reserved seats in the synagogues;

Chapter 23.23:7: they love to be greeted with respect in the marketplaces and to have people call them Teacher.

Chapter 23.23:8: You must not be called Teacher, because you are all equal and have only one Teacher.

Chapter 23.23:9: And you must not call anyone here on earth Father, because you have only the one Father in heaven.

Chapter 23.23:10: Nor should you be called Leader, because your one and only leader is the Messiah.

Chapter 23.23:11: The greatest one among you must be your servant.

Chapter 23.23:12: Whoever makes himself great will be humbled, and whoever humbles himself will be made great.

Chapter 23.23:13: How terrible for you, teachers of the Law and Pharisees! You hypocrites! You lock the door to the Kingdom of heaven in people's faces, but you yourselves don't go in, nor do you allow in those who are trying to enter!

Chapter 23.23:15: How terrible for you, teachers of the Law and Pharisees! You hypocrites! You sail the seas and cross whole countries to win one convert; and when you succeed, you make him twice as deserving of going to hell as you yourselves are!

Chapter 23.23:16: How terrible for you, blind guides! You teach, If someone swears by the Temple, he isn't bound by his vow; but if he swears by the gold in the Temple, he is bound.

Chapter 23.23:17: Blind fools! Which is more important, the gold or the Temple which makes the gold holy?

Chapter 23.23:18: You also teach, If someone swears by the altar, he isn't bound by his vow; but if he swears by the gift on the altar, he is bound.

Chapter 23.23:19: How blind you are! Which is the more important, the gift or the altar which makes the gift holy?

Chapter 23.23:20: So then, when a person swears by the altar, he is swearing by it and by all the gifts on it;

Chapter 23.23:21: and when he swears by the Temple, he is swearing by it and by God, who lives there;

Chapter 23.23:22: and when someone swears by heaven, he is swearing by God's throne and by him who sits on it.

Chapter 23.23:23: How terrible for you, teachers of the Law and Pharisees! You hypocrites! You give to God one tenth even of the seasoning herbs, such as mint, dill, and cumin, but you neglect to obey the really important teachings of the Law, such as justice and mercy and honesty. These you should practice, without neglecting the others.

Chapter 23.23:24: Blind guides! You strain a fly out of your drink, but swallow a camel!

Chapter 23.23:25: How terrible for you, teachers of the Law and Pharisees! You hypocrites! You clean the outside of your cup and plate, while the inside is full of what you have gotten by violence and selfishness.

Chapter 23.23:26: Blind Pharisee! Clean what is inside the cup first, and then the outside will be clean too!

Chapter 23.23:27: How terrible for you, teachers of the Law and Pharisees! You hypocrites! You are like whitewashed tombs, which look fine on the outside but are full of bones and decaying corpses on the inside.

Chapter 23.23:28: In the same way, on the outside you appear good to everybody, but inside you are full of hypocrisy and sins.

Chapter 23.23:29: How terrible for you, teachers of the Law and Pharisees! You hypocrites! You make fine tombs for the prophets and decorate the monuments of those who lived good lives;

Chapter 23.23:30: and you claim that if you had lived during the time of your ancestors, you would not have done what they did and killed the prophets.

Chapter 23.23:31: So you actually admit that you are the descendants of those who murdered the prophets!

Chapter 23.23:32: Go on, then, and finish up what your ancestors started!

Chapter 23.23:33: You snakes and children of snakes! How do you expect to escape from being condemned to hell?

Chapter 23.23:34: And so I tell you that I will send you prophets and wise men and teachers; you will kill some of them, crucify others, and whip others in the synagogues and chase them from town to town.

Chapter 23.23:35: As a result, the punishment for the murder of all innocent people will fall on you, from the murder of innocent Abel to the murder of Zechariah son of Berechiah, whom you murdered between the Temple and the altar.

Chapter 23.23:36: I tell you indeed: the punishment for all these murders will fall on the people of this day!

Chapter 23.23:37: Jerusalem, Jerusalem! You kill the prophets and stone the messengers God has sent you! How many times I wanted to put my arms around all your people, just as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you would not let me!

Chapter 23.23:38: And so your Temple will be abandoned and empty.

Chapter 23.23:39: From now on, I tell you, you will never see me again until you say, God bless him who comes in the name of the Lord.

Chapter 24.24:1: Jesus left and was going away from the Temple when his disciples came to him to call his attention to its buildings.

Chapter 24.24:2: Yes, he said, you may well look at all these. I tell you this: not a single stone here will be left in its place; every one of them will be thrown down.

Chapter 24.24:3: As Jesus sat on the Mount of Olives, the disciples came to him in private. Tell us when all this will be, they asked, and what will happen to show that it is the time for your coming and the end of the age.

Chapter 24.24:4: Jesus answered, Watch out, and do not let anyone fool you.

Chapter 24.24:5: Many men, claiming to speak for me, will come and say, I am the Messiah! and they will fool many people.

Chapter 24.24:6: You are going to hear the noise of battles close by and the news of battles far away; but do not be troubled. Such things must happen, but they do not mean that the end has come.

Chapter 24.24:7: Countries will fight each other; kingdoms will attack one another. There will be famines and earthquakes everywhere.

Chapter 24.24:8: All these things are like the first pains of childbirth.

Chapter 24.24:9: Then you will be arrested and handed over to be punished and be put to death. Everyone will hate you because of me.

Chapter 24.24:10: Many will give up their faith at that time; they will betray one another and hate one another.

Chapter 24.24:11: Then many false prophets will appear and fool many people.

Chapter 24.24:12: Such will be the spread of evil that many people's love will grow cold.

Chapter 24.24:13: But whoever holds out to the end will be saved.

Chapter 24.24:14: And this Good News about the Kingdom will be preached through all the world for a witness to all people; and then the end will come.

Chapter 24.24:15: You will see The Awful Horror of which the prophet Daniel spoke. It will be standing in the holy place. Note to the reader: understand what this means!

Chapter 24.24:16: Then those who are in Judea must run away to the hills.

Chapter 24.24:17: Someone who is on the roof of a house must not take the time to go down and get any belongings from the house.

Chapter 24.24:18: Someone who is in the field must not go back to get a cloak.

Chapter 24.24:19: How terrible it will be in those days for women who are pregnant and for mothers with little babies!

Chapter 24.24:20: Pray to God that you will not have to run away during the winter or on a Sabbath!

Chapter 24.24:21: For the trouble at that time will be far more terrible than any there has ever been, from the beginning of the world to this very day. Nor will there ever be anything like it again.

Chapter 24.24:22: But God has already reduced the number of days; had he not done so, nobody would survive. For the sake of his chosen people, however, God will reduce the days.

Chapter 24.24:23: Then, if anyone says to you, Look, here is the Messiah! or There he is!—do not believe it.

Chapter 24.24:24: For false Messiahs and false prophets will appear; they will perform great miracles and wonders in order to deceive even God's chosen people, if possible.

Chapter 24.24:25: Listen! I have told you this ahead of time.

Chapter 24.24:26: Or, if people should tell you, Look, he is out in the desert!—don't go there; or if they say, Look, he is hiding here!—don't believe it.

Chapter 24.24:27: For the Son of Man will come like the lightning which flashes across the whole sky from the east to the west.

Chapter 24.24:28: Wherever there is a dead body, the vultures will gather.

Chapter 24.24:29: Soon after the trouble of those days, the sun will grow dark, the moon will no longer shine, the stars will fall from heaven, and the powers in space will be driven from their courses.

Chapter 24.24:30: Then the sign of the Son of Man will appear in the sky; and all the peoples of earth will weep as they see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.

Chapter 24.24:31: The great trumpet will sound, and he will send out his angels to the four corners of the earth, and they will gather his chosen people from one end of the world to the other.

Chapter 24.24:32: Let the fig tree teach you a lesson. When its branches become green and tender and it starts putting out leaves, you know that summer is near.

Chapter 24.24:33: In the same way, when you see all these things, you will know that the time is near, ready to begin.

Chapter 24.24:34: Remember that all these things will happen before the people now living have all died.

Chapter 24.24:35: Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will never pass away.

Chapter 24.24:36: No one knows, however, when that day and hour will come—neither the angels in heaven nor the Son; the Father alone knows.

Chapter 24.24:37: The coming of the Son of Man will be like what happened in the time of Noah.

Chapter 24.24:38: In the days before the flood people ate and drank, men and women married, up to the very day Noah went into the boat;

Chapter 24.24:39: yet they did not realize what was happening until the flood came and swept them all away. That is how it will be when the Son of Man comes.

Chapter 24.24:40: At that time two men will be working in a field: one will be taken away, the other will be left behind.

Chapter 24.24:41: Two women will be at a mill grinding meal: one will be taken away, the other will be left behind.

Chapter 24.24:42: Watch out, then, because you do not know what day your Lord will come.

Chapter 24.24:43: If the owner of a house knew the time when the thief would come, you can be sure that he would stay awake and not let the thief break into his house.

Chapter 24.24:44: So then, you also must always be ready, because the Son of Man will come at an hour when you are not expecting him.

Chapter 24.24:45: Who, then, is a faithful and wise servant? It is the one that his master has placed in charge of the other servants to give them their food at the proper time.

Chapter 24.24:46: How happy that servant is if his master finds him doing this when he comes home!

Chapter 24.24:47: Indeed, I tell you, the master will put that servant in charge of all his property.

Chapter 24.24:48: But if he is a bad servant, he will tell himself that his master will not come back for a long time,

Chapter 24.24:49: and he will begin to beat his fellow servants and to eat and drink with drunkards.

Chapter 24.24:50: Then that servant's master will come back one day when the servant does not expect him and at a time he does not know.

Chapter 24.24:51: The master will cut him in pieces and make him share the fate of the hypocrites. There he will cry and gnash his teeth.

Chapter 25.25:1: At that time the Kingdom of heaven will be like this. Once there were ten young women who took their oil lamps and went out to meet the bridegroom.

Chapter 25.25:2: Five of them were foolish, and the other five were wise.

Chapter 25.25:3: The foolish ones took their lamps but did not take any extra oil with them,

Chapter 25.25:4: while the wise ones took containers full of oil for their lamps.

Chapter 25.25:5: The bridegroom was late in coming, so they began to nod and fall asleep.

Chapter 25.25:6: It was already midnight when the cry rang out, Here is the bridegroom! Come and meet him!

Chapter 25.25:7: The ten young women woke up and trimmed their lamps.

Chapter 25.25:8: Then the foolish ones said to the wise ones, Let us have some of your oil, because our lamps are going out.

Chapter 25.25:9: No, indeed, the wise ones answered, there is not enough for you and for us. Go to the store and buy some for yourselves.

Chapter 25.25:10: So the foolish ones went off to buy some oil; and while they were gone, the bridegroom arrived. The five who were ready went in with him to the wedding feast, and the door was closed.

Chapter 25.25:11: Later the others arrived. Sir, sir! Let us in! they cried out.

Chapter 25.25:12: Certainly not! I don't know you, the bridegroom answered.

Chapter 25.25:13: And Jesus concluded, Watch out, then, because you do not know the day or the hour.

Chapter 25.25:14: At that time the Kingdom of heaven will be like this. Once there was a man who was about to leave home on a trip; he called his servants and put them in charge of his property.

Chapter 25.25:15: He gave to each one according to his ability: to one he gave five thousand gold coins, to another he gave two thousand, and to another he gave one thousand. Then he left on his trip.

Chapter 25.25:16: The servant who had received five thousand coins went at once and invested his money and earned another five thousand.

Chapter 25.25:17: In the same way the servant who had received two thousand coins earned another two thousand.

Chapter 25.25:18: But the servant who had received one thousand coins went off, dug a hole in the ground, and hid his master's money.

Chapter 25.25:19: After a long time the master of those servants came back and settled accounts with them.

Chapter 25.25:20: The servant who had received five thousand coins came in and handed over the other five thousand. You gave me five thousand coins, sir, he said. Look! Here are another five thousand that I have earned.

Chapter 25.25:21: Well done, you good and faithful servant! said his master. You have been faithful in managing small amounts, so I will put you in charge of large amounts. Come on in and share my happiness!

Chapter 25.25:22: Then the servant who had been given two thousand coins came in and said, You gave me two thousand coins, sir. Look! Here are another two thousand that I have earned.

Chapter 25.25:23: Well done, you good and faithful servant! said his master. You have been faithful in managing small amounts, so I will put you in charge of large amounts. Come on in and share my happiness!

Chapter 25.25:24: Then the servant who had received one thousand coins came in and said, Sir, I know you are a hard man; you reap harvests where you did not plant, and you gather crops where you did not scatter seed.

Chapter 25.25:25: I was afraid, so I went off and hid your money in the ground. Look! Here is what belongs to you.

Chapter 25.25:26: You bad and lazy servant! his master said. You knew, did you, that I reap harvests where I did not plant, and gather crops where I did not scatter seed?

Chapter 25.25:27: Well, then, you should have deposited my money in the bank, and I would have received it all back with interest when I returned.

Chapter 25.25:28: Now, take the money away from him and give it to the one who has ten thousand coins.

Chapter 25.25:29: For to every person who has something, even more will be given, and he will have more than enough; but the person who has nothing, even the little that he has will be taken away from him.

Chapter 25.25:30: As for this useless servant—throw him outside in the darkness; there he will cry and gnash his teeth.

Chapter 25.25:31: When the Son of Man comes as King and all the angels with him, he will sit on his royal throne,

Chapter 25.25:32: and the people of all the nations will be gathered before him. Then he will divide them into two groups, just as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats.

Chapter 25.25:33: He will put the righteous people at his right and the others at his left.

Chapter 25.25:34: Then the King will say to the people on his right, Come, you that are blessed by my Father! Come and possess the kingdom which has been prepared for you ever since the creation of the world.

Chapter 25.25:35: I was hungry and you fed me, thirsty and you gave me a drink; I was a stranger and you received me in your homes,

Chapter 25.25:36: naked and you clothed me; I was sick and you took care of me, in prison and you visited me.

Chapter 25.25:37: The righteous will then answer him, When, Lord, did we ever see you hungry and feed you, or thirsty and give you a drink?

Chapter 25.25:38: When did we ever see you a stranger and welcome you in our homes, or naked and clothe you?

Chapter 25.25:39: When did we ever see you sick or in prison, and visit you?

Chapter 25.25:40: The King will reply, I tell you, whenever you did this for one of the least important of these followers of mine, you did it for me!

Chapter 25.25:41: Then he will say to those on his left, Away from me, you that are under God's curse! Away to the eternal fire which has been prepared for the Devil and his angels!

Chapter 25.25:42: I was hungry but you would not feed me, thirsty but you would not give me a drink;

Chapter 25.25:43: I was a stranger but you would not welcome me in your homes, naked but you would not clothe me; I was sick and in prison but you would not take care of me.

Chapter 25.25:44: Then they will answer him, When, Lord, did we ever see you hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison, and we would not help you?

Chapter 25.25:45: The King will reply, I tell you, whenever you refused to help one of these least important ones, you refused to help me.

Chapter 25.25:46: These, then, will be sent off to eternal punishment, but the righteous will go to eternal life.

Chapter 26.26:1: When Jesus had finished teaching all these things, he said to his disciples,

Chapter 26.26:2: In two days, as you know, it will be the Passover Festival, and the Son of Man will be handed over to be crucified.

Chapter 26.26:3: Then the chief priests and the elders met together in the palace of Caiaphas, the High Priest,

Chapter 26.26:4: and made plans to arrest Jesus secretly and put him to death.

Chapter 26.26:5: We must not do it during the festival, they said, or the people will riot.

Chapter 26.26:6: Jesus was in Bethany at the house of Simon, a man who had suffered from a dreaded skin disease.

Chapter 26.26:7: While Jesus was eating, a woman came to him with an alabaster jar filled with an expensive perfume, which she poured on his head.

Chapter 26.26:8: The disciples saw this and became angry. Why all this waste? they asked.

Chapter 26.26:9: This perfume could have been sold for a large amount and the money given to the poor!

Chapter 26.26:10: Jesus knew what they were saying, and so he said to them, Why are you bothering this woman? It is a fine and beautiful thing that she has done for me.

Chapter 26.26:11: You will always have poor people with you, but you will not always have me.

Chapter 26.26:12: What she did was to pour this perfume on my body to get me ready for burial.

Chapter 26.26:13: Now, I assure you that wherever this gospel is preached all over the world, what she has done will be told in memory of her.

Chapter 26.26:14: Then one of the twelve disciples—the one named Judas Iscariot—went to the chief priests

Chapter 26.26:15: and asked, What will you give me if I betray Jesus to you? They counted out thirty silver coins and gave them to him.

Chapter 26.26:16: From then on Judas was looking for a good chance to hand Jesus over to them.

Chapter 26.26:17: On the first day of the Festival of Unleavened Bread the disciples came to Jesus and asked him, Where do you want us to get the Passover meal ready for you?

Chapter 26.26:18: Go to a certain man in the city, he said to them, and tell him: The Teacher says, My hour has come; my disciples and I will celebrate the Passover at your house.

Chapter 26.26:19: The disciples did as Jesus had told them and prepared the Passover meal.

Chapter 26.26:20: When it was evening, Jesus and the twelve disciples sat down to eat.

Chapter 26.26:21: During the meal Jesus said, I tell you, one of you will betray me.

Chapter 26.26:22: The disciples were very upset and began to ask him, one after the other, Surely, Lord, you don't mean me?

Chapter 26.26:23: Jesus answered, One who dips his bread in the dish with me will betray me.

Chapter 26.26:24: The Son of Man will die as the Scriptures say he will, but how terrible for that man who will betray the Son of Man! It would have been better for that man if he had never been born!

Chapter 26.26:25: Judas, the traitor, spoke up. Surely, Teacher, you don't mean me? he asked. Jesus answered, So you say.

Chapter 26.26:26: While they were eating, Jesus took a piece of bread, gave a prayer of thanks, broke it, and gave it to his disciples. Take and eat it, he said; this is my body.

Chapter 26.26:27: Then he took a cup, gave thanks to God, and gave it to them. Drink it, all of you, he said;

Chapter 26.26:28: this is my blood, which seals God's covenant, my blood poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins.

Chapter 26.26:29: I tell you, I will never again drink this wine until the day I drink the new wine with you in my Father's Kingdom.

Chapter 26.26:30: Then they sang a hymn and went out to the Mount of Olives.

Chapter 26.26:31: Then Jesus said to them, This very night all of you will run away and leave me, for the scripture says, God will kill the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.

Chapter 26.26:32: But after I am raised to life, I will go to Galilee ahead of you.

Chapter 26.26:33: Peter spoke up and said to Jesus, I will never leave you, even though all the rest do!

Chapter 26.26:34: Jesus said to Peter, I tell you that before the rooster crows tonight, you will say three times that you do not know me.

Chapter 26.26:35: Peter answered, I will never say that, even if I have to die with you! And all the other disciples said the same thing.

Chapter 26.26:36: Then Jesus went with his disciples to a place called Gethsemane, and he said to them, Sit here while I go over there and pray.

Chapter 26.26:37: He took with him Peter and the two sons of Zebedee. Grief and anguish came over him,

Chapter 26.26:38: and he said to them, The sorrow in my heart is so great that it almost crushes me. Stay here and keep watch with me.

Chapter 26.26:39: He went a little farther on, threw himself face downward on the ground, and prayed, My Father, if it is possible, take this cup of suffering from me! Yet not what I want, but what you want.

Chapter 26.26:40: Then he returned to the three disciples and found them asleep; and he said to Peter, How is it that you three were not able to keep watch with me for even one hour?

Chapter 26.26:41: Keep watch and pray that you will not fall into temptation. The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak.

Chapter 26.26:42: Once more Jesus went away and prayed, My Father, if this cup of suffering cannot be taken away unless I drink it, your will be done.

Chapter 26.26:43: He returned once more and found the disciples asleep; they could not keep their eyes open.

Chapter 26.26:44: Again Jesus left them, went away, and prayed the third time, saying the same words.

Chapter 26.26:45: Then he returned to the disciples and said, Are you still sleeping and resting? Look! The hour has come for the Son of Man to be handed over to the power of sinners.

Chapter 26.26:46: Get up, let us go. Look, here is the man who is betraying me!

Chapter 26.26:47: Jesus was still speaking when Judas, one of the twelve disciples, arrived. With him was a large crowd armed with swords and clubs and sent by the chief priests and the elders.

Chapter 26.26:48: The traitor had given the crowd a signal: The man I kiss is the one you want. Arrest him!

Chapter 26.26:49: Judas went straight to Jesus and said, Peace be with you, Teacher, and kissed him.

Chapter 26.26:50: Jesus answered, Be quick about it, friend! Then they came up, arrested Jesus, and held him tight.

Chapter 26.26:51: One of those who were with Jesus drew his sword and struck at the High Priest's slave, cutting off his ear.

Chapter 26.26:52: Put your sword back in its place, Jesus said to him. All who take the sword will die by the sword.

Chapter 26.26:53: Don't you know that I could call on my Father for help, and at once he would send me more than twelve armies of angels?

Chapter 26.26:54: But in that case, how could the Scriptures come true which say that this is what must happen?

Chapter 26.26:55: Then Jesus spoke to the crowd, Did you have to come with swords and clubs to capture me, as though I were an outlaw? Every day I sat down and taught in the Temple, and you did not arrest me.

Chapter 26.26:56: But all this has happened in order to make come true what the prophets wrote in the Scriptures. Then all the disciples left him and ran away.

Chapter 26.26:57: Those who had arrested Jesus took him to the house of Caiaphas, the High Priest, where the teachers of the Law and the elders had gathered together.

Chapter 26.26:58: Peter followed from a distance, as far as the courtyard of the High Priest's house. He went into the courtyard and sat down with the guards to see how it would all come out.

Chapter 26.26:59: The chief priests and the whole Council tried to find some false evidence against Jesus to put him to death;

Chapter 26.26:60: but they could not find any, even though many people came forward and told lies about him. Finally two men stepped up

Chapter 26.26:61: and said, This man said, I am able to tear down God's Temple and three days later build it back up.

Chapter 26.26:62: The High Priest stood up and said to Jesus, Have you no answer to give to this accusation against you?

Chapter 26.26:63: But Jesus kept quiet. Again the High Priest spoke to him, In the name of the living God I now put you under oath: tell us if you are the Messiah, the Son of God.

Chapter 26.26:64: Jesus answered him, So you say. But I tell all of you: from this time on you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right side of the Almighty and coming on the clouds of heaven!

Chapter 26.26:65: At this the High Priest tore his clothes and said, Blasphemy! We don't need any more witnesses! You have just heard his blasphemy!

Chapter 26.26:66: What do you think? They answered, He is guilty and must die.

Chapter 26.26:67: Then they spat in his face and beat him; and those who slapped him

Chapter 26.26:68: said, Prophesy for us, Messiah! Guess who hit you!

Chapter 26.26:69: Peter was sitting outside in the courtyard when one of the High Priest's servant women came to him and said, You, too, were with Jesus of Galilee.

Chapter 26.26:70: But he denied it in front of them all. I don't know what you are talking about, he answered,

Chapter 26.26:71: and went on out to the entrance of the courtyard. Another servant woman saw him and said to the men there, He was with Jesus of Nazareth.

Chapter 26.26:72: Again Peter denied it and answered, I swear that I don't know that man!

Chapter 26.26:73: After a little while the men standing there came to Peter. Of course you are one of them, they said. After all, the way you speak gives you away!

Chapter 26.26:74: Then Peter said, I swear that I am telling the truth! May God punish me if I am not! I do not know that man! Just then a rooster crowed,
